prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: (This repeats the science case for the CO(2-1) observations) We want to observe the strength and expansion velocities of the CO J=3-2 and J=2-1 lines in Bands 7 and 6. The expansion velocities we expect to measure are between a few km/s and 30 km/s. We thus want to choose a spectral resolution yielding a velocity accuracy of ~1 km/s, using the 937.5 MHz / 488 kHz (0.635 km/s) spectral setup for CO (2--1) and 1875 MHz/ 977 kHz (0.849 km/s) for CO (3--2). We will use one window covering the 230.538 GHz CO(2--1) and the 345.796 GHZ CO (3--2) transitions and use the remaining windows to measure the continuum and any serindipitous lines (e.g. CO+). To determine the sensitivity we want to achieve, we estimate the peak flux density of each source using Equation 7 of Olofsson (2008): S_CO(2−1) ~ 6 . (MLR)^1.2 . (v_exp/15)^-1.6 . (f(CO)/0.001)^0.7 . (1/D)^2 Jy where MLR is the mass-loss rate in units of 10^-6 Msun/yr, v_exp is wind velocity in km/s, f(CO) is the fraction of mass lost in CO and D is distance in kpc. We would typically expect a mass-loss rate of 10^-6 Msun/yr, an expansion velocity of ~15 km/s, f(CO) = 0.0001 or higher, depending on the exact C/O ratio, and D between 6 and 15 kpc. This yields an expected flux obetween 16 and 54 mJy in CO(2-1) and 32 and 127 mJy in CO (3-2). We anticipate a factor of ten uncertainty in this value, as it is precisely the above parameters which we are trying to determine. We only require a signal-to-noise ratio of ~10 or more over the entire line to determine the mass-loss rate and wind velocity with sufficient accuracy. For each object, this can be reach within a few minutes and the total time is dominated by overheads, we thus require ~30mn per object and transition, hence 4 hours for the whole project

(This repeats the science case for the CO(2-1) observations) We want to observe the strength and expansion velocities of the CO J=3-2 and J=2-1 lines in Bands 7 and 6. (f(CO)/0.001)^0.7 . (1/D)^2 Jy where MLR is the mass-loss rate in units of 10^-6 Msun/yr, v_exp is wind velocity in km/s, f(CO) is the fraction of mass lost in CO and D is distance in kpc. We would typically expect a mass-loss rate of 10^-6 Msun/yr, an expansion velocity of ~15 km/s, f(CO) = 0.0001 or higher, depending on the exact C/O ratio, and D between 6 and 15 kpc. This yields an expected flux obetween 16 and 54 mJy in CO(2-1) and 32 and 127 mJy in CO (3-2). We anticipate a factor of ten uncertainty in this value, as it is precisely the above parameters which we are trying to determine. We only require a signal-to-noise ratio of ~10 or more over the entire line to determine the mass-loss rate and wind velocity with sufficient accuracy. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We will use ALMA to measure the CO J=3-2 and J=2-1 transition in a sample offour evolved stars in globular clusters spanning a range of metallicities, but with otherwise similar properties. The ALMA observations will give us outflow velocities and CO mass-loss rates, which will lead to estimates of the total mass-loss rates. Coupling these data with infrared spectroscopy from the Spitzer Space Telescope, we can assess how overall mass-loss rate, outflow velocity and gas-to-dust mass ratio depend on metallicity for stars on the asymptotic giant branch (AGB). We will be able to diagnose whether stellar pulsation or radiation pressure on dust drive the mass loss, as a function of metallicity. The result will be our most quantitative understanding yet of how mass loss depends on metallicity for AGB stars.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Center for Radiophysics and Space Research, Cornell University

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Center for Radiophysics and Space Research, Cornell University

Institute for Scientific Research, Boston College

School of Science, The University of Tokyo

Earth and Space Sciences, Chalmers University of Technology
Center for Radiophysics and Space Research, Cornell University
